One-and-One Free Throws: Simulating a Probability Situation

In the district finals, Nishi’s basketball team is 1 point behind with 2 seconds left. A player on the other team fouls Nishi.

She is in a one-and-one free-throw situation.

This means that Nishi will try one free throw.

  • If she makes it, she tries a second free throw.
  • If she misses the first free throw, she does not get to try a second free throw.

What does it mean to say that Nishi’s free throw average is 60%?

What are the possible points Nishi can get in a one-in-one situation?
